refs.title: The Ancient Maya
refs.author: Robert J. Sharer & Loa P. Traxler (2006)
refs.note: The definitive scholarly survey of Maya civilisation across all periods.

refs.title: The Aztecs: A Very Short Introduction
refs.author: David Carrasco (2011)
refs.note: Concise and authoritative overview of Aztec society, religion, and empire.

refs.title: The Incas
refs.author: Terence N. D'Altroy (2014)
refs.note: Comprehensive account of Inca state organisation, economy, and culture.

refs.title: The Olmecs: America's First Civilization
refs.author: Richard A. Diehl (2004)
refs.note: Standard reference on the Olmec heartland and their broader cultural influence.

refs.title: Dumbarton Oaks — Pre-Columbian Studies
refs.author: Harvard University
refs.note: Peer-reviewed research and digital library covering all Pre-Columbian cultures.

refs.title: The Greeks: A Portrait of Self and Others
refs.author: Paul Cartledge (2002)
refs.note: Accessible yet rigorous exploration of Greek identity, politics, and society.

refs.title: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome
refs.author: Mary Beard (2015)
refs.note: Acclaimed modern history questioning traditional narratives of Rome's rise.

refs.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire
refs.author: Peter Heather (2006)
refs.note: Argues for external pressures — Huns and Goths — as the primary cause of Rome's collapse.

refs.title: Byzantium: The Surprising Life of a Medieval Empire
refs.author: Judith Herrin (2007)
refs.note: Engagingly written introduction to the Byzantine world and its lasting legacy.

refs.title: The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy
refs.author: Jacob Burckhardt (1860)
refs.note: The foundational text that established the concept of the Renaissance as a historical period.

refs.title: The Origins of the Industrial Revolution
refs.author: T.S. Ashton (1948)
refs.note: Concise classic on the social and economic preconditions for British industrialisation.

refs.title: The Wealth of Nations
refs.author: Adam Smith (1776)
refs.note: Written at the dawn of the Industrial Revolution; foundational text of modern economics.

refs.title: Perseus Digital Library — Greek & Roman Texts
refs.author: Tufts University
refs.note: Free access to primary Greek and Roman sources in original languages and translation.

refs.title: The Sumerians: Their History, Culture, and Character
refs.author: Samuel Noah Kramer (1963)
refs.note: Classic introduction to Sumerian civilisation by one of the field's founding scholars.

refs.title: Babylon: Mesopotamia and the Birth of Civilization
refs.author: Paul Kriwaczek (2010)
refs.note: Sweeping narrative of Mesopotamian history from the earliest cities to the fall of Babylon.

refs.title: The Persians
refs.author: Geoffrey Parker & Brenda Parker (2008)
refs.note: Readable overview of Achaemenid, Parthian, and Sasanid Persian civilisations.

refs.title: The House of Wisdom
refs.author: Jim Al-Khalili (2010)
refs.note: Traces the scientific achievements of the Islamic Golden Age and their transmission to Europe.

refs.title: Lord of the Horizons: A History of the Ottoman Empire
refs.author: Jason Goodwin (1998)
refs.note: Vivid narrative history of the Ottoman world from rise to dissolution.

refs.title: Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature
refs.author: University of Oxford
refs.note: Full translations of Sumerian literary texts including the Epic of Gilgamesh.

refs.title: The Oxford History of Ancient Egypt
refs.author: Ian Shaw, ed. (2000)
refs.note: Multi-author scholarly reference covering all periods of ancient Egyptian history.

refs.title: Black Kingdoms of the Nile (Nubia)
refs.author: Vivian Davies & Renée Friedman (1998)
refs.note: Explores the sophisticated cultures of Nubia, including the Kingdom of Kush.

refs.title: The African Past: Chronicles from Antiquity to Modern Times
refs.author: Basil Davidson (1964)
refs.note: Pioneering work covering Carthage, Axum, the Mali Empire, and African history broadly.

refs.title: Mansa Musa and the Empire of Mali
refs.author: P. James Oliver (2013)
refs.note: Account of the Mali Empire and its ruler, reportedly the wealthiest person in history.

refs.title: British Museum — Ancient Egypt Collection
refs.author: British Museum
refs.note: Extensive digitised collection with scholarly catalogue entries for Egyptian artefacts.

refs.title: The Indus Civilization: A Contemporary Perspective
refs.author: Gregory L. Possehl (2002)
refs.note: The most thorough modern assessment of Harappan archaeology and society.

refs.title: Ashoka: The Search for India's Lost Emperor
refs.author: Charles Allen (2012)
refs.note: Compelling narrative of the Mauryan emperor and the archaeological detective work to find him.

refs.title: The Gupta Empire
refs.author: Radhakumud Mookerji (1959)
refs.note: Classic scholarly account of the Gupta golden age in literature, science, and mathematics.

refs.title: The Mughal Empire
refs.author: John F. Richards (1993)
refs.note: Part of the New Cambridge History of India; authoritative political and economic history.

refs.title: AIIS Digital South Asia Library
refs.author: University of Chicago
refs.note: Primary sources, maps, and scholarly materials on South Asian history from the Indus Valley to modern India.

refs.title: The Early Chinese Empires: Qin and Han
refs.author: Mark Edward Lewis (2007)
refs.note: Part of the Harvard History of Imperial China series; covers the Han Dynasty in depth.

refs.title: China's Golden Age: Everyday Life in the Tang Dynasty
refs.author: Charles Benn (2002)
refs.note: Rich cultural history of Tang society, commerce, and cosmopolitanism.

refs.title: The Age of Confucian Rule: The Song Transformation of China
refs.author: Dieter Kuhn (2009)
refs.note: Detailed exploration of Song Dynasty innovations in technology, governance, and culture.

refs.title: Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World
refs.author: Jack Weatherford (2004)
refs.note: Revisionist account of the Mongol Empire's role in accelerating global exchange.

refs.title: The Bronze Age of China
refs.author: Wen Fong, ed. (1980)
refs.note: Landmark exhibition catalogue on Shang and Zhou bronzes; a reference for early Chinese civilisation.

refs.title: Asia for Educators — Columbia University
refs.author: Columbia University
refs.note: Curriculum materials and scholarly resources on Chinese and Asian history from the Shang through the modern era.

civs: Sophisticated city-states with their own writing system, precise astronomical calendar, mathematical zero, and monumental jungle pyramids.
Andean civilisation famed for monumental stone architecture at 3,800 m altitude, raised-field agriculture, and wide Andean trade networks.
Tenochtitlán was among the largest cities on Earth (~200,000 people). Advanced agriculture, astronomy, tribute empire, and sophisticated governance.
The Aztecs: A Very Short Introduction
Without writing or the wheel, the Inca built 40,000 km of roads, advanced terraced agriculture, extraordinary masonry, and administered a vast empire via quipus.
Europe's first major civilisation: a Bronze Age maritime culture on Crete with sophisticated frescoes, Linear A writing, indoor plumbing, and wide Mediterranean trade.
Philosophy, democracy, geometry, logic, and drama. Aristotle, Plato, Euclid, and Archimedes shaped Western thought for two thousand years.
The Greeks: A Portrait of Self and Others
Aqueducts, roads, concrete, codified law — a cosmopolitan culture spanning three continents, the foundation of modern Western civilisation.
SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome
The Fall of the Roman Empire
Eastern Rome preserved Greco-Roman knowledge, produced exquisite mosaics and architecture, and served as Europe's eastern bulwark for over a millennium.
Byzantium: The Surprising Life of a Medieval Empire
Rebirth of art, science, and humanism. The printing press, heliocentrism, and advances in anatomy laid the groundwork for the Scientific Revolution.
The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy
Humanity's first cities and the first writing system (cuneiform). Also credited with the wheel, the sail, and the 60-minute hour still in use today.
The Sumerians: Their History, Culture, and Character
Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature
The world's first true empire, unifying Mesopotamian city-states under Sargon of Akkad with centralised bureaucracy and a standardised written language.
Babylon: Mesopotamia and the Birth of Civilization
Hammurabi's law code, advanced astronomy enabling eclipse prediction, sophisticated mathematics, and a spectacular city that awed ancient visitors.
Babylon: Mesopotamia and the Birth of Civilization
Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature
Master seafarers who spread the alphabet — ancestor of nearly every writing system used today — across the Mediterranean world.
The largest empire of its era: the Royal Road, religious tolerance, standardised currency, a sophisticated postal system, and satrapy administration.
Advanced algebra, optics, medicine, and philosophy. Al-Khwarizmi and Ibn Sina were centuries ahead of the European West.
A long-lived empire bridging Europe and Asia, renowned for law, monumental architecture, military innovation, and tolerance of diverse peoples.
Lord of the Horizons: A History of the Ottoman Empire
Monumental architecture, hieroglyphic writing, advanced mathematics and medicine. A remarkably stable civilisation lasting over three thousand years.
The Oxford History of Ancient Egypt
Nubian kingdom that conquered Egypt and ruled as its 25th Dynasty, with its own pyramids at Meroë, unique writing, and advanced iron smelting.
A mercantile powerhouse and dominant naval force of the western Mediterranean — controlling North African and Iberian trade routes until Rome destroyed it.
East African empire that minted its own coins, adopted Christianity early, built towering stelae, and controlled the lucrative Red Sea trade route.
Mansa Musa's empire was home to Timbuktu — a centre of Islamic scholarship — and was once the wealthiest state on Earth per contemporary accounts.
Mansa Musa and the Empire of Mali
Grid-layout cities, underground sewage systems, standardised weights and measures. Mohenjo-daro was among the most sophisticated cities of its age.
The Indus Civilization: A Contemporary Perspective
Developed Sanskrit literature, early mathematics, the Upanishads, and social-religious structures that shaped Indian civilisation for millennia.
India's first major empire under Chandragupta and Ashoka — spreading Buddhism, building roads, and issuing one of history's earliest animal welfare edicts.
Ashoka: The Search for India's Lost Emperor
A golden age of Indian mathematics (decimal system, formalised zero), astronomy, literature, and medicine. Chess was likely invented in this period.
Produced the Taj Mahal, a codified legal system, and unprecedented religious syncretism under Akbar the Great — ruling a third of humanity at its peak.
Advanced bronze metallurgy, oracle bone writing, organised military, and the deep roots of continuous Chinese civilisation.
China's longest dynasty. The era of Confucius, Laozi, and the Hundred Schools of Thought — a philosophical flowering that shaped East Asia permanently.
Contemporaneous with Rome in scale, the Han built the Silk Road, invented paper and the seismoscope, and established the Confucian bureaucracy.
The Early Chinese Empires: Qin and Han
A cosmopolitan golden age of printing, gunpowder, poetry, and governance. Chang'an was likely the world's largest city.
China's Golden Age: Everyday Life in the Tang Dynasty
Remarkable innovation: movable-type printing, gunpowder weapons, the magnetic compass, and early coal-based industrialisation — centuries before Europe.
The Age of Confucian Rule: The Song Transformation of China
The largest contiguous land empire in history. Facilitated the Pax Mongolica — unprecedented cultural and commercial exchange across Eurasia.
Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World
Steam power transformed manufacturing, transport, and society. Britain became the first industrial nation, triggering global modernisation that spread across Europe and beyond.

America rapidly industrialised after Britain, surpassing it by 1900. Mass production (Ford), electrification, and the rise of Silicon Valley made the US the dominant industrial power of the 20th century.
The Origins of the Industrial Revolution
European colonisation imposed industrial-era economies across Africa, followed by independence movements from the 1950s onward. Africa's modern states are still shaped by this transformation.
Independence from Britain (1947) launched South Asia into rapid modernisation, with India emerging as a major technology and economic power by the 21st century.
The discovery of oil, the collapse of the Ottoman Empire, and the redrawing of borders after WWI and WWII shaped the contemporary Middle East, which now sits at the centre of global energy supply.

Japan's Meiji Restoration (1868) launched the first non-Western industrialisation. South Korea, Taiwan, and China followed in the 20th–21st centuries, producing the world's largest economies.
